Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2008 05:42AM second-twin wrote: Hi brst26 Good luck with your radiation.   I started having radiation in 1998, then 2001, 2002, 2005,2006,2007, and again in January 2008!!!   So if I count the radiation "spots", it should be about 7/800 by now!! ( Not "showing off", just letting you know what I have been through!)  All I can say to you is that in 1998 it was a nightmare, but last year and this year was very much easier.    I kept patting on Maizena (South African word for Cornflour) and was very careful not to go into the sun at all.    Radiation makes you feel rather exhausted at times I can't deny that, (although not daily) and I seem to get through radiation easier than I do chemotherapy which I have had 12 times to date!!  I'm on Xeloda at the moment and that is heavy going.   But look after your skin, watch it carefully for redness and you will be fine.   I have Stage 4 Advanced Breast Cancer but still fighting fit and living life to the full. ciao second-twin

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 03:48PM second-twin wrote: Hi Miniota Don't wait 6 months - it is far too long to wait.   Insist on having a scan immediately, it is not worth it.   My cancer started in the breast and is now in the chest wall and I certainly didn't wait.   Rather be safe than sorry, it might just be benign, then you can celebrate, but the worst thing about cancer and results is the waiting period.   I don't know that the doctors even realise how stressful that can be. Good luck secondtwin

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 08:53PM second-twin wrote: 11.03.2008 Hi there Tracey I was on Xeloda and navelbine in 2002 but at the moment am only on Xeloda for a couple of weeks.    Once the oncologist is satisfied that the Xeloda is taking effect or not, she might add Navelbine again.   Cancer is all consuming at the best of times.   Today i celebrate life.  Today is the 10th anniversary of being diagnosed with breast cancer and to date, I have been re-diagnosed 11 more times!   It is an ongoing battle but I have survived having 12 chemotherapy and 7 radiation sessions over the last 10 years, and although I feel unique having survived all these toxins in my body, I still have hope that I will continue fighting this disease.   It is harder for the family around me than it is for myself, as they see the bad days more clearly than I see myself.    Hang in there, every year there are new drugs on the market and you are not alone. secondtwin
